contextId.occurrenceNote: “in the past.” This refers to the time before the people of Jerusalem were captured. Alternate translation: “before this disaster happened” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in former days

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they enemy army has become too large and powerful and has defeated Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “the enemy army has defeated me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the enemy has become too great

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means they traded their wealth and their valuables in exchange for food. Alternate translation: “They have traded their precious treasures in exchange for food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They have given their precious treasures for food

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they betrayed him. Alternate translation: “they betrayed me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they were treacherous toward me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “inside the house, everyone is dying” or (2) “and inside the house the dead people are kept” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: inside the house there is only death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a request for Jerusalem’s enemies to suffer as the people of Jerusalem have. Alternate translation: “now let them suffer like me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: now let them become like me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a request for Yahweh to punish Jerusalem’s enemies as he punished the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “punish them as you have punished me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: deal with them as you have dealt with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means for them to request that the Lord save their children. Alternate translation: “to save the lives of your children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for the lives of your children

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied here that this refers to dead people. Alternate translation: “The corpses of both the young and the old lie on the dust” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Both the young and the old lie on the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be expressed clearly that this refers to commanding something to happen. Alternate translation: “has commanded that something should happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: has spoken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) it is implied that mere people cannot fully understand God’s actions. Alternate translation: “How can a mere person complain” or (2) it is implied that being alive is a gift from God. Alternate translation: “How can a person who is blessed to be alive complain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: How can any person alive complain

contextId.occurrenceNote: What the author hopes Yahweh will see can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “until Yahweh looks down from heaven and sees what has happened to my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: until Yahweh from heaven looks down and sees

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that the “daughters of my city” are suffering. Alternate translation: “because the daughters of my city are suffering” or “because I see the daughters of my city suffering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: because of all the daughters of my city

contextId.occurrenceNote: “their bodies were redder than coral.” This implies that they were healthy. Alternate translation: “their bodies were healthy and red” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: their bodies were more ruddy than coral

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that there was not much muscle or fat under the skin. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Their skin has shriveled on their bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “Our end” refers to the end of living in their own city because their enemies would destroy the city and capture them. Alternate translation: “Our destruction” or “Our capture” or (2) “Our end” refers to the end of their lives. Alternate translation: “Our death” or “The time for us to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Our end

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that their enemies are making them pay money to have the water and wood that they once used for free. Alternate translation: “We have to pay silver to our enemies in order to drink our own water … our own wood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: We must pay silver for the water we drink & our own wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “Now the people who rule over us are themselves slaves to their own masters in Babylon” or (2) “People who used to be slaves in Babylon now rule over us.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Slaves rule over us

contextId.occurrenceNote: The boys are forced to carry the loads of wood. Alternate translation: “boys stagger because they are forced to carry heavy loads of wood” or “they force the boys to carry heavy loads of wood which make them stagger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: boys stagger under heavy loads of wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they have a hard time seeing because they are crying. Alternate translation: “and we can hardly see because our eyes are full of tears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for these things our eyes grow dim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Often people would sit on the ground to show they were mourning. Alternate translation: “sit on the ground, mourning in silence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: sit on the ground in silence

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are actions of mourning. Alternate translation: “To show their mourning, they have thrown dust on their heads and put on sackcloth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: They have thrown dust on their heads and put on sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an action of mourning. Alternate translation: “have sorrowfully bowed their heads to the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: have bowed their heads to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: These actions are used to mock and insult others. Alternate translation: “mock you by clapping their hands … hiss and shake their heads” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: clap their hands & hiss and shake their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: This action shows a person’s anger and that they are mocking others. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: grind their teeth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was an action often performed while praying. Alternate translation: “Lift up your hands to him in prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Lift up your hands to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exclamation that shows the author’s sadness that this has happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: how the purest gold has changed

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Various poetic forms are used throughout this book. (See [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

A new poem begins. The writer of Lamentations uses many different ways to express that the people of Israel have lost God’s favor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

A new poem begins. See [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]].
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

A new poem begins. See [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]].
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks to the walls of Jerusalem. He wants the people of Jerusalem to do what he is telling the walls to do. Some translations take this whole section to be spoken to the “walls,” though this can be written with the first phrase “walls of the daughter of Zion!” spoken to the “walls,” and the rest of the section spoken directly to the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: walls of the daughter of Zion! Make your tears flow & no relief

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues speaking to the walls of Jerusalem. He wants the people of Jerusalem to do what he is telling the walls to do. Some translations take this whole section to be spoken to the “walls,” though this can be written with the first phrase “walls of the daughter of Zion!” spoken to the “walls,” and the rest of the section spoken directly to the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise, cry out & of every street

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated without the double negatives. Also, here the Lord is referred to by his “hand.” Alternate translation: “with his hand he has destroyed the wall” or “he has destroyed the wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: has not withheld his hand from destroying

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “wails” refers to the sounds that a person makes when they “weep” loudly. Alternate translation: “weeps loudly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: weeps and wails

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words share similar meanings. Together they invite the reader to understand by seeing that no one has suffered so much. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Look and see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wormwood is a plant that gives a liquid which is very bitter to drink. Together “wormwood” and “bitterness” represent severe suffering. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: wormwood and bitterness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “transgressed” and “rebelled” share similar meanings. Together they indicate that transgression is the same as rebelling against Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: We have transgressed and rebelled

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words share similar meanings and refer to the destruction of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “total destruction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: ruin and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases means the same thing. The author speaks of his continuing to cry as if his eyes were a person and had no rest from crying. Alternate translation: “without stopping” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: without ceasing, without relief

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that these are people who desired to harm Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “any kind of enemy” or “any of Jerusalem’s enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: enemies or opponents

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Rejoice” and “be glad” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of gladness. The writer uses these words to mock the people. He knew that the people of Edom would be glad that Jerusalem is being destroyed. Alternate translation: “Be very glad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Rejoice and be glad

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” refers to their enemies. This is a euphemism that means that they were murdered by their enemies. Alternate translation: “My young women and my young men have been murdered by their enemies” or “My enemies have murdered my young women and my young men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: My young women and my young men have fallen by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to them being dead. Alternate translation: “they have died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: they are no more

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “every” here is an exaggeration for “many.” Alternate translation: “where the streets come together” or “by the roads” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: at the corner of every street

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “all” is a generalization, meaning “most.” Alternate translation: “a laughingstock to most of my people” or “someone whom all my people mock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: a laughingstock to all my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “her fall” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “Her downfall was astonishing” or “Those who saw her destruction were surprised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Her fall was terrible

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “has taken possession of” or “has stolen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: has put his hand on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “day” is used as an idiom. Alternate translation: “when he was fiercely angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on the day of his fierce anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on high

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “prevented my from walking any further” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: turned me back

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I cannot resist them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am not able to stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the day” is an idiom that refers to a specific event happening. Alternate translation: “You have done what you have promised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: You have brought the day you promised

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a request for Yahweh to judge Jerusalem’s enemies for their wickedness. The phrase “come before you” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “Pay attention to all of the wickedness they have committed” or “Judge them for all of their wickedness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Let all their wickedness come before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “day” is used as an idiom that refers to a general period of time. Alternate translation: “at the time when he displays his anger” or “at the time he acts in his anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on the day of his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “day” is used as an idiom that refers to a general period of time. Alternate translation: “the time of his anger” or “the time of his anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the days of his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “have shouted victoriously” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: have raised a shout

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I have cried until I cannot cry anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: My eyes have failed from their tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “We have greatly desired to see it happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: We have lived to see it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “pour out your heart like water” is an idiom. Here the Lord is represented by his “face” to emphasize his presence. Alternate translation: “Tell the Lord how you feel in your inner being” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “to attack from every direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on every side

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “day” is used as an idiom that refers to a general period of time. Alternate translation: “at the time when Yahweh acted in his anger” or “during the time that Yahweh displayed his anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on the day of the anger of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks about God refusing to listen to his prayers as though God was shutting his ears so that the author’s prayers could not go into them. Alternate translation: “he refuses to hear my prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he shut out my prayer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people in general. Alternate translation: “human beings” or “people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the children of mankind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the women of Jerusalem or (2) all the inhabitants of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: all the daughters of my city

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Remember” here is an idiom. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, think about what has happened to us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Remember, Yahweh, what has happened to us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase “given ourselves” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “We have made a treaty with Egypt and with Assyria so that we would have food to eat” or “We have surrendered to Egypt and to Assyria to have enough food to remain alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: We have given ourselves to Egypt and to Assyria to get enough food

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “always” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from generation to generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this idiom refers to the duration of God’s life. Since God lives forever, it can also be translated as “forever.” Perhaps the writer was uing hyperbole and exaggerating the length of time he believed that God was forsaking them. Alternate translation: “for as long as you live” or “forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: for the length of your days

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an ironic comparison between the happy, noisy festivals of Israel and the loud shouts of victory of the Babylonians. Alternate translation: “They have raised a shout in the house of Yahweh, as the Israelites would during an appointed feast” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: They have raised a shout in the house of Yahweh, as on the day of an appointed feast

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two opposite times of day refer to all the time. Alternate translation: “all of the time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: day and night

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two actions together represent everything the people do. Alternate translation: “everything they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: how they sit and then rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the city of Jerusalem being empty, as if it were a woman who was sitting alone. Alternate translation: “is now empty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: is now sitting all alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem being honored as if it were a princess. Alternate translation: “She was like a princess among the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: She was a princess among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people groups that had been faithful to Jerusalem betraying Jerusalem, as if the people groups were Jerusalem’s lovers and friends. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: None of her lovers comfort her & ll her friends have betrayed her

contextId.occurrenceNote: According to the l of Moses, a woman was considered unclean during her monthly bleeding. This speaks of Jerusalem being unclean, as if it were a menstruating woman. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem has become unclean, as when a woman is unclean beneath her skirts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: She has become unclean beneath her skirts

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers to be spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Jerusalem’s sins as if they were a yoke bearing a heavy burden that Yahweh had placed on their necks. Also, If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “My transgressions are like a yoke that he has bound together with his hands and placed upon my neck” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The yoke of my transgressions & They are knit together and placed upon my neck

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the enemy army attacking Jerusalem is spoken of as if it were a meeting of people who have come together in order to accuse and condemn someone. Alternate translation: “a great army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: an assembly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the judgment of God is described as if Jerusalem were grapes on which he had trampled in order to squeeze out the juice. Alternate translation: “It is as though the Lord has trampled upon the virgin daughter of Judah in a winepress” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord has trampled & in the winepress

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. The word “virgin” suggests that this woman is pure. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the virgin daughter of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem having no one to comfort her as if she did have a comforter, but that he was far away. The word “comforter” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “for there is no one to comfort me and restore my life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for a comforter is far from me, one who restores my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “churn” means to move around violently, normally in a circular rotation. This does not mean the stomach is literally churning, but describes how the woman, representing Jerusalem, feels. Alternate translation: “my insides ache” or “my stomach hurts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my stomach churns

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the Lord’s anger against Jerusalem (Zion) as if it were a dark cloud. This could mean: (1) God is threatening to harm the people of Jerusalem or (2) God has already harmed the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord has covered the daughter of Zion under the cloud of his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the splendor of Israel” refers to Jerusalem. This passage speaks of the people of Jerusalem losing favor with the Lord as if he threw them out of his presence. The phrase “from heaven to earth” is a great distance used to represent how much they lost favor with the Lord. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem, the splendor of Israel, has lost all favor with the Lord” or “Jerusalem has lost all favor with the Lord” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He has thrown the splendor of Israel down from heaven to earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a reference to the Lord having considered Jerusalem his “footstool” in the past, which symbolized that he had authority over them and that they were submissive to him. This speaks of the Lord disregarding Jerusalem as his footstool as if he did not remember them. Alternate translation: “He disregarded Jerusalem as his footstool” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He has not remembered his footstool

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the Lord not paying attention to Jerusalem as if he did not remember them. Alternate translation: “disregarded” or “paid no attention to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: not remembered

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the Lord completely destroying the towns as if he were an animal who ate them. Alternate translation: “completely destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: swallowed up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the Lord taking away Israel’s strength as if he were cutting off its horns. The word “horn” refers to an animal horn, not a musical instrument. Alternate translation: “he has taken away all of Israel’s strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has cut off every horn of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the Lord’s wrath as if it were a liquid that he were pouring out on the people. His wrath is also compared to a “fire” to emphasize how destructive it is. Alternate translation: “in his anger he has destroyed everything like a blazing fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has poured out his wrath like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of preparing to destroy the wall as if he measured it before he destroyed it, so that he knew how much to destroy. Alternate translation: “It is as though he has measured the wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He has stretched out the measuring line

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “churn” means to move around violently, normally in a circular rotation. This does not mean the stomach is literally churning, but describes how the author feels. Alternate translation: “my insides ache” or “my stomach hurts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my stomach churns

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of feeling grief in his inner being as if his inner body parts had fallen out of his body onto the ground. Alternate translation: “my entire inner being is in grief” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my inner parts are poured out to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the children dying as if their lives were a liquid that was being poured out. Alternate translation: “they slowly die in the arms of their mothers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their lives are poured out on the bosom of their mothers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people speak of destroying Jerusalem as if they were an animal swallowing its food. Alternate translation: “We have completely destroyed Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: We have swallowed her up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people crying so much that their tears would flow like a river. Alternate translation: “Cry many, many tears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Make your tears flow down like a river

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of children having come from their mother as if they were fruit that came from her womb. Alternate translation: “their children that they have given birth to” or “their own children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fruit of their wombs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “has seen” represents has experienced. Alternate translation: “who has experienced misery” or “who has suffered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who has seen misery

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “darkness” represents suffering. Alternate translation: “caused me to suffer terribly with no hope, like a person walking in darkness rather than light” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: caused me to walk in darkness rather than light

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the author speaks of God causing bad things to happen to him as if he were a city and God was an enemy that built up siege works against him. Alternate translation: “God attacked me like an enemy army that sets up siege works around a city” or (2) the author speaks of God causing the enemy army to attack Jerusalem as if God were the enemy. Alternate translation: “God caused the enemy army to build up siege works against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He built up siege works against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents God causing him to experience much bitterness and hardship. Alternate translation: “caused me to experience much bitterness and hardship” or “caused me to suffer and have many problems” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: surrounded me with bitterness and hardship

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bitterness” represents suffering. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: bitterness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “dark places” is a metaphor for suffering. The author compares the intensity of his suffering to the intensity of the darkness that those who died long ago experience. Alternate translation: “The suffering that he causes me is intense like the darkness of the grave” or “He makes me suffer terribly, as if I were in the darkness of those who died long ago” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He made me live in dark places, like those who died long ago

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the continuing suffering. Like a person who cannot escape from prison, the author cannot make his suffering stop. Alternate translation: “My suffering continues. It is as though he has built a wall around me and put heavy chains on me, and I cannot escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He built a wall around me and I cannot escape & e made my chains heavy

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of God causing him to continue to suffer as if God was preventing him from escaping the suffering by blocking his path. Alternate translation: “It is as though he blocked my path” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He blocked my path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Crooked paths do not lead people to where they want to go. Here they represent unsuccessful ways of escaping suffering. Alternate translation: “it is as though he has made my paths crooked” or “I have tried to make the suffering stop, but God has prevented me, like one who prevents another from escaping by making his paths crooked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he made my paths crooked

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the deep grief he feels as if God had shot his kidneys with an arrow. Alternate translation: “My grief is great. It is as if he pierced my kidneys with the arrows of his quiver” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He pierced my kidneys with the arrows of his quiver

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kidneys are abdominal organs that move urine into the bladder. They are a metaphor for a person’s emotions. Alternate translation: “deep into my body” or “my heart” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my kidneys

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bitterness” represents suffering. It is referred to as if it were something that could fill the speaker. Alternate translation: “He has caused me to suffer very much” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He filled me with bitterness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wormwood is the bitter juice from the leaves and flowers of a certain plant. Drinking that bitter juice represents suffering. Alternate translation: “it is as though he forced me to drink something very bitter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: forced me to drink wormwood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the author speaks of God humiliating him as if God had forced him to chew gravel. Alternate translation: “He has humiliated me, like someone who forces another to chew gravel” or (2) the author speaks of God humiliating him as if God had pushed his face down into the gravel on the ground. Alternate translation: “He has humiliated me, like someone who pushes another man’s face down into the gravel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He has made my teeth grind with gravel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of God humiliating him as if God had pushed him down into the ashes of a fire on the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he made me cower in the ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “they” refers to God’s steadfast love and compassions. Their being new represents God continuing to act according to them. Alternate translation: “every morning he treats us again with steadfast love and compassion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they are new every morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: When God gave each tribe of Israel their land, he called it an inheritance. The author speaks of Yahweh being all he needs as if Yahweh were the inheritance that he had received. Alternate translation: “Because Yahweh is with me, I have everything I need” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh is my inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **seeks him** could mean: (1) asking God for help or (2) wanting to know God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who seeks him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bear the yoke” represents suffering. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **his youth**, you can express the same idea with another word such as “young.” Alternate translation: “that he suffer while he is young” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: that he bear the yoke in his youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: “when the yoke is laid upon him.” Here the yoke represents suffering. Alternate translation: “when he suffers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when it is laid upon him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” refers to anyone who is suffering and who waits for Yahweh. Here “offer his cheek” represents allowing someone to strike his cheek. Alternate translation: “Let him allow people to hit him on the face” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Let him offer his cheek to the one who strikes him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of a person as if he were a container and reproach were a liquid. Being filled with reproach represents being reproached much. The implication is that he should be patient when this happens. Alternate translation: “let him be insulted much” or “let him be patient when people reproach him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: let him be filled to the full with reproach

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “crush underfoot” represents abusing and mistreating people. Alternate translation: “To abuse” or “To mistreat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])-
contextId.quoteString: To crush underfoot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “come” represents happening. Also, the nominal adjective “the good” can be stated as “good things.” Alternate translation: “both calamities and good things happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: both calamities and the good come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “return to Yahweh” represents submitting to him again. Alternate translation: “let us submit to Yahweh again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: let us return to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lift up our hearts” represents praying sincerely. It was customary for the Israelites to raise their hands when praying to God. Alternate translation: “Let us pray sincerely with lifted hands” or “Let us lift up our hands and pray sincerely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Let us lift up our hearts and our hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here anger is spoken of as if it were a garment that God has put on. Hebrew often spoke of emotions as if they were clothing. Alternate translation: “You have been angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have covered yourself with anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “spared” represents having pity. Alternate translation: “you have not had pity on us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have not spared

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents God refusing to listen to the people’s prayer. Alternate translation: “You refuse to listen to our prayers. It is as though you put a cloud between us and you so that our prayers cannot get to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have covered yourself with a cloud so that no prayer can pass through

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author speaks of the great amount of his tears as if they were streams. He uses exaggeration to show that he is very sad and has cried much. Alternate translation: “Tears flow from my eyes like water flowing in a river” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: My eyes flow with streams of tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of people looking for him in order to kill him as if he were an animal that they were hunting. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “My enemies have looked for me in order to kill me like people who hunt for a bird” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have been hunted like a bird by those who were my enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being “cut off” often represents being killed. Here it represents dying very soon. Alternate translation: “I am about to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have been cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of God keeping him from being killed by his enemies as if God had defended him in court as a lawyer defends someone, and kept him from being killed. Alternate translation: “you saved my life from my enemies. It is as though you defended me in court” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you defended my case, you saved my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “defended my case” represents arguing for him. Alternate translation: “you argued my case for me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you defended my case

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is no longer pictured as a lawyer, but as the judge. It can be stated clearly that he wanted God to judge in his favor. Alternate translation: “make a decision about me, and show my enemies that I am right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: judge my case

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of his enemies accusing him all day as if their accusations were soldiers that come to attack him all day. Alternate translation: “My enemies speak against me and accuse me through the whole day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The lips and the accusations & come against me all the day

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Pay back to them” represents punishing them. What they have done can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Punish them, Yahweh, according to what they have done” or “Yahweh, they have made me suffer, so please make them suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Pay back to them, Yahweh, according to what they have done

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Jerusalem are spoken of as if they were gold that is no longer shiny, and therefore no longer valuable. Alternate translation: “The people of Jerusalem are like gold that is no longer shiny. They are like pure gold that is no longer beautiful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The gold has become tarnished; how the purest gold has changed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may refer to the temple being destroyed and its stones scattered throughout the city. It may also be a metaphor for the people being scattered. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The holy stones are scattered at the corner of every street

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people of a city are spoken of as if they were the sons of the city. This could mean: (1) this refers to only the young men of Jerusalem or (2) this refers to all the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: sons of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the precious sons of Zion as if they were considered to be inexpensive clay jars. Alternate translation: “people consider them to be as worthless as the clay jars that potters make” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they are worth no more than clay jars, the work of the potter’s hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Jerusalem’s leaders were beautiful to look at because they were physically healthy or (2) the leaders were morally pure as new snow and milk are pure white. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Her leaders were purer than snow, whiter than milk

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s punishing his people is spoken of as if his anger were a burning hot liquid that he poured out on them. Alternate translation: “because of his fierce anger, he punished his people” or “in fierce anger he responded to his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he poured out his fierce anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The priests and prophets are spoken of as if they were blind because they wandered through the streets, not knowing where to go. Alternate translation: “They wandered through the streets like blind men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They wandered, blind, through the streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “defiled” represents being unacceptable to God. Because the priests and prophets murdered people, they were ritually unclean, unable to worship God or be with ordinary people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They were so defiled by that blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “watched” represents hoping. It can be stated clearly that they were hoping that a nation would come and rescue them. Alternate translation: “we hoped for a nation to come and rescue us, but it could not rescue us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: we watched for a nation that could not rescue us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “near” is a metaphor for “soon.” Alternate translation: “Our end would be soon” or “Our enemies would soon destroy us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Our end was near

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being numbered represents being so few that they could be easily counted. Alternate translation: “we had very little time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: our days were numbered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “had come” means that what they had expected was now happening. Alternate translation: “it was now the end for us” or “our enemies were attacking us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: our end had come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “pits” refers to the enemies’ plans to capture him. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he was the one whom our enemies captured by their plans” or “our enemies made plans to capture our king, and they did capture him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he was the one who was captured in their pits

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his shadow” represents him protecting them. Alternate translation: “Under his protection we will live among the nations” or “Though we may have to live in other nations, he will protect us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Under his shadow we will live among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The cup is a metonym for the wine in it. The wine is a metaphor for punishment. Alternate translation: “But Yahweh will also punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But to you also the cup will be passed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the sins not being known by others are spoken of as if they are under a cover. Removing the cover represents letting other people know about them. Alternate translation: “he will expose your sins” or “he will cause other people to know how you have sinned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will uncover your sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Jerusalem have no one to protect them because the men have either died in battle or have gone into exile. This speaks of the people not having their fathers and husbands present as if they had actually become orphans and widows. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: We have become orphans & our mothers are like widows

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of being able to rest as if “rest” were an object that could be found. Alternate translation: “we are unable to rest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: we can find no rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Playing music was part of the social life at the city gate. This speaks of the men no longer playing their music as if the act of playing music were a place that they left. Alternate translation: “the young men have stopped playing their music” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the young men have left their music

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Judah refers to its inhabitants. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah have gone into exile” or “the people of Judah have been taken into a foreign land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah has gone into exile

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” refers to the people who live there. The phrase “call to mind” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “the people of Jerusalem will remember” or “Jerusalem will remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers the control of the enemy army. Alternate translation: “When the adversary conquered and captured her people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: When her people fell into the hand of the adversary

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fire” represents pain and “bones” represents one’s inner being. Alternate translation: “has sent pain into my bones” or “has sent pain into my inner being” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: has sent fire into my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: “given me over into the hands of my enemies.” Here their enemies’ control is represented by their “hands.” Alternate translation: “given my over to the control of my enemies” or “let my enemies defeat me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: given me over into their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” refers to his descendants, that is Israel. Alternate translation: “around Jacob’s descendants should be their adversaries” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: around Jacob should be his adversaries

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “sword” represents the enemy. Alternate translation: “the enemy kills a mother’s children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword bereaves a mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the towns of Jacob” refers to the towns where his descendants lived. Alternate translation: “all the towns of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the towns of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Lord’s protection is represented by his “right hand.” Alternate translation: “stopped protecting us from our enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: withdrawn his right hand from before the enemy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” refers to the places where his descendants lived. Alternate translation: “Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Lord caused Israel’s enemies to destroy it. He did not destroy it himself. Alternate translation: “He has caused the place of the solemn assembly to be destroyed” or “He has caused their enemies to destroy the place of the solemn assembly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He has destroyed the place of the solemn assembly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the enemy’s “hand” refers to the enemy’s control. Alternate translation: “He has allowed the enemy to capture the walls of her palaces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He has given over the walls of her palaces into the hand of the enemy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh chose to have the wall destroyed and caused Jerusalem’s enemy to destroy it. He did not destroy it himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh decided to destroy the city wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name of Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used as a request for something to eat. The children are telling their mother that they are hungry. The phrase “grain and wine” represents food and drink. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Give us something to eat and drink.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is grain and wine?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **horn** (that is, an animal horn) represents strength. Alternate translation: “he has increased the power of your enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he has lifted up the horn of your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh allowing the poeple to be slaughtered as if he killed them himself. Alternate translation: “you allowed them to be slaughtered” or “you allowed this to happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you have slaughtered them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people the author fears are referred to as his “terrors.” Alternate translation: “the attackers I was afraid of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my terrors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being “under the rod” represents being beaten with a rod. The author speaks of God’s punishment as if God had beaten him with a rod. Alternate translation: “because Yahweh was very angry and has beaten me with a rod” or “because Yahweh was very angry and has punished me severely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: under the rod of Yahweh’s fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “turned his hand against me” represents attacking him. The author speaks of God causing bad things to happen to him as if God had attacked him. Alternate translation: “he has attacked me” or “he has caused many bad things to happen to me, like someone who attacks a person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he turned his hand against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the heart represents desire or pleasure, and afflicting from the heart represents afflicting with pleasure. Alternate translation: “For it does not make him happy to afflict people” or “He does not take pleasure in afflicting people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For he does not afflict from his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doing something “in the presence of the Most High” represents doing it while knowing that God sees it. Alternate translation: “knowing that the Most High sees it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in the presence of the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to teach that both calamities and good things happen only because God has commanded them to happen. Alternate translation: “It is only from the mouth of the Most High that both calamities and the good come.” or “It is only because the Most High has commanded it that both calamities and good things happen.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not from the mouth of the Most High that both calamities and the good come?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouth” represents what God says or commands. Alternate translation: “from the command of the Most High” or “because the Most High has commanded it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the mouth of the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “My eyes” represents what he sees. Alternate translation: “What I see causes me to grieve” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: My eyes cause me grief

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s name represents his character, and here, “called on your name” represents trusting God’s character and calling on him for help. Alternate translation: “I called to you for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I called on your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents what he said. Alternate translation: “You heard my words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You heard my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “close your ear” represents refusing to listen. Alternate translation: “Do not refuse to listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not close your ear

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often come near to a person they help. Here “came near” represents helping the man. Alternate translation: “you helped me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You came near

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the lips represent what his enemies say. Alternate translation: “The words … of my enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The lips & of my enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “heart” is a metonym that represents their attitudes and emotions, and being “shameless” means not feeling ashamed of their sins even though they should. Their not being ashamed would give even more reason for God to punish them. Alternate translation: “You will let them feel no shame for their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will let their hearts be shameless

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “from under the heavens” represents everywhere on earth. Alternate translation: “wherever they are on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from under the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this phrase is a metonym for luxurious, expensive, and comfortable clothing, at least some of which was probably scarlet. Alternate translation: “luxurious clothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: scarlet clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: People sometimes rub and twist their hands when they are worried and cannot fix something, so wringing the hands here represents worrying. The word “her” refers to Jerusalem, which was called “the daughter of my people.” Alternate translation: “no one was worried about her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: no hands were wrung for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents an enemy’s attack. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Those whom enemy soldiers have killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Those who have been killed by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hunger” represents starvation. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those who starved to death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]]and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: those killed by hunger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “harvest from the field” is a metonym that represents food to eat. Lack of food is spoken of here as if it were a sword that pierces people. Alternate translation: “who died because there was not enough food to eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: pierced by the lack of any harvest from the field

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents God causing Israel’s enemies to start a fire in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “He caused a fire to start in Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He kindled a fire in Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the priests and the prophets were guilty of murder. Here “shed the blood” represents murder. Alternate translation: “who have murdered the righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who have shed the blood of the righteous

contextId.occurrenceNote: “defiled by the blood that they shed.” This could mean: (1) the blood was on their clothes or (2) “blood” is a metonym for murder. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: defiled by that blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “watch over them” represents being concerned about them and helping them. Alternate translation: “he does not care about them anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he does not watch over them anymore

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their eyes failing represents their seeking and not being able to find what they were looking for. These two phrases together emphasize that they were trying hard to find help. Alternate translation: “We continued looking, but we could not find anyone to help us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Our eyes failed, looking in vain for help

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “our steps” represents where they went. Alternate translation: “Our enemies followed us everywhere we went” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They followed our steps

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “iniquities” represents the punishment received because of their ancestors’ sins. Alternate translation: “we bear the punishment for their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: we bear their iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to control. Alternate translation: “to rescue us from their control” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to deliver us from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bread” refers to food in general. Alternate translation: “food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here robbers with swords are represented by their “swords.” Alternate translation: “because there are robbers in the wilderness who kill others with swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because of the sword in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “We no longer wear flowers on our heads for celebrations” or (2) The “crown” represents their king and their “head” represents a place of authority over the people. Alternate translation: “We no longer have a king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The crown has fallen from our head

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “heart” represents a person’s emotions. This speaks of a person being discouraged as if their emotions were sick. Alternate translation: “Because of this we are discouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For this our heart has become sick

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sitting on the throne represents ruling as king. Alternate translation: “rule as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sit upon your throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh was very angry, and he did everything he wanted to do to show that he was angry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh showed all his wrath; he poured out his fierce anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines share similar meanings and emphasize that these spiritual leaders were largely responsible for the fall of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “the terrible sins of her prophets and priests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: the sins of her prophets and the iniquities of her priests

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning and emphasize that the people no longer have their fathers. Alternate translation: “orphans who have no fathers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: orphans, the fatherless

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meaning and emphasize that the women are being violated. The words “are raped” are understood in the second part of this sentence and can be repeated. Alternate translation: “Women are raped in Zion, and virgins are raped in the cities of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Women are raped in Zion, and virgins in the cities of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer of Lamentations writes about the city of Jerusalem as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: She

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author describes Jerusalem as having emotions like a human being. The city also stands for her inhabitants. Alternate translation: “Those who live in her weep and wail … and their tears cover their cheeks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: She weeps and wails & and her tears cover her cheeks

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In these verses, Jerusalem and Judah are spoken of as if they were women. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the kingdom of Judah is described as a woman. “She” also stands for the citizens of Judah. Alternate translation: “Her people live … they find” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: She lives & finds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Judah being captured by their enemies as if they were a woman who was captured by those pursuing her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: All her pursuers overtook her in her desperation

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The city of Zion is spoken of as if it were a woman. In Lamentations, Zion and Jerusalem are names used to refer to the same city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the roads that lead to Zion mourning as if they were human beings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The roads of Zion mourn

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Zion. Alternate translation: “All of Zion’s gates are empty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: All her gates are desolate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people of Zion being distressed are spoken of as if they were a woman in distress. Alternate translation: “Zion’s virgins are sorrowful, and its people despairing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Her virgins are sorrowful and she herself is in complete distress

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing the people of Zion for their sins as if they were a woman that Yahweh was punishing. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has afflicted her people because of the sins they have committed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has afflicted her for her many sins

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The city of Zion is spoken of as if it were a woman. In Lamentations, Zion and Jerusalem are names used to refer to the same city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The city of Jerusalem is spoken of as if it were a woman. In Lamentations, Zion and Jerusalem are names used to refer to the same city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes Jerusalem as a woman who sinned, while it also stands for the inhabitants of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “The people of Jerusalem sinned greatly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem sinned greatly

contextId.occurrenceNote: “her naked.” Jerusalem is described as a woman whose private parts have been exposed to everyone to shame her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: her nakedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean that: (1) the author of Lamentations now talks directly to Yahweh or (2) Jerusalem is described as talking to Yahweh like a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Look at my affliction, Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “She” refers to Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: She has seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Jerusalem which is described as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “her inhabitants” or “the people of the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: her people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jerusalem speaks directly to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Look, Yahweh, and consider me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jerusalem continues to speak, but now to people who pass by instead of to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it nothing to you

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this section Jerusalem is portrayed as a woman speaking about herself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing Jerusalem as if Jerusalem were a person that Yahweh were punishing with fire. Alternate translation: “he has sent a painful punishment into my inner being, and it has destroyed me” or “he has sent a destructive punishment into the middle of Jerusalem, and it has destroyed the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has sent fire into my bones, and it has conquered them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing Jerusalem as if Jerusalem were a person that Yahweh had set a trap for. This refers to a type of trap usually used to catch an animal. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He has spread a net for my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this section Jerusalem is portrayed as a woman speaking about herself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this section Jerusalem is portrayed as a woman speaking about herself. In Lamentations, Zion and Jerusalem are names used to refer to the same city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jerusalem no longer speaks about herself; instead the author describes Jerusalem. He speaks of Zion as if it were a woman that lifts up her hands to ask for help. Alternate translation: “Zion has reached out for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Zion has spread her hands wide

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this section Jerusalem is portrayed as a woman speaking about herself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this section Jerusalem is portrayed as a woman speaking about herself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem continues to talk about herself as if she were a woman, but now talks directly to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Look, Yahweh, for I am in distress

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this section Jerusalem is portrayed as a woman speaking about herself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: “People have heard my groaning.” Jerusalem continues to speak as if she were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: They have heard my groaning

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “daughter of Zion” is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. The phrase “tent of the daughter of Zion” speaks of Jerusalem as a “tent” emphasizing that it is the home of those who live there. Alternate translation: “who live in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the tent of the daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The walls and ramparts are spoken of as if they were people who lamented and died. Alternate translation: “Because he has destroyed the ramparts and walls, they are like people who lament and have lost their strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: He has made the ramparts and wall to lament; together they wasted away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are poetic names for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. “Zion” is another name for Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Jerusalem & virgin daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks as if his ability to endure more suffering and his hope that Yahweh will help him were living beings that have died. Alternate translation: “I cannot endure anymore suffering and I can no longer hope that Yahweh will help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: My endurance has perished and so has my hope in Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of the land of Edom are spoken of as if they were a woman. They were Israel’s enemy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Jerusalem are spoken of as if they were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])\
contextId.quoteString: Daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is an accusation aganist the people who walk past Jerusalem and do not care about its well-being. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “All you who pass by should care more for my affliction!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to express that he does not know what to say to help Jerusalem. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is nothing that I can say … Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What can I say & Jerusalem?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to express that he does not know how to give comfort to Jerusalem. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is nothing to which I can compare you … Zion.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: To what can I compare to you & Zion?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Who can restore you?” The author uses this rhetorical question to express that there is no one who can restore Jerusalem to the way it was before. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can heal you.” or “No one can restore you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who can heal you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used to express sarcasm. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “This city that they called ‘The Perfection of Beauty,’ ‘The Joy for All of Earth,’ is not so beautiful or joyful anymore!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is this the city that they called ‘The Perfection of Beauty,’ ‘The Joy for All of Earth’?
