contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is asked to emphasize that it is not right for women to eat their children. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Woman should not eat their own children … for!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should women eat the fruit of their wombs & for?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used to emphasize that the prophets and priests should not be killed. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The prophets and priests should not be slaughtered in the sanctuary of the Lord!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should priest and prophet be slaughtered in the sanctuary of the Lord?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to teach that when someone commands something to happen, it will happen only if God has already decreed that it should happen. Alternate translation: “No one has spoken and it came to pass, unless the Lord decreed it.” or “What someone has commanded to happen has never happened unless the Lord decreed it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has spoken and it came to pass, unless the Lord decreed it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses these rhetorical questions to teach that people should not complain when God punishes them. Alternate translation: “A person should not complain when God punishes him for his sins.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How can any person alive complain? How can a person complain about the punishment for his sins?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses these rhetorical questions to express his feelings that Yahweh has forgotten them. These questions can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: “It is as though you will forget us forever or not come back to us for a very long time!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you forget us forever? Why do you forsake us for the length of your days?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem as being without protection, as if it were a vulnerable widow. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a widow

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Zion’s princes having nothing to eat like deer that cannot find grass to eat. Alternate translation: “Her princes are starving, they are like deer that cannot find grass to eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Her princes have become like deer that cannot find pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem being scorned in the same way that a woman is scorned when she is unclean. According to the law of Moses, a woman was considered unclean during her monthly bleeding. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem’s sins have made her filthy and unclean, and therefore she was unacceptable before God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem sinned greatly, therefore, she has become scorned as something that is filthy

contextId.occurrenceNote: A soldier has to bend his bow in order to shoot an arrow from it. This speaks of the Lord preparing to attack Israel as if he were an enemy about to shoot them with a bow and arrow. Alternate translation: “He has prepared to kill us, like an enemy who has made his bow ready to shoot us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like an enemy he has bent his bow toward us, with his right is ready to shoot

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the tabernacle being easily destroyed, as if it were a garden hut. The Lord caused Israel’s enemies to destroy it. He did not destroy it himself. Alternate translation: “He has caused their enemies to attack his tabernacle as easily as if it were a garden hut” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He has attacked his tabernacle like a garden hut

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the children fainting from hunger and thirst in the same way that a wounded man faints. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as they faint like a wounded man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Jerusalem’s great suffering as if it were as terrible as the sea is great. Alternate translation: “Your suffering is as terrible as the sea is large” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Your wound is as great as the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: “as if they were coming to a feast.” This speaks of how Yahweh summoned his enemies as if he were inviting them to a feast. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as you would call the people to a feast day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of God being ready to cause him to suffer more, as if God were a wild animal waiting to attack him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He is like a bear waiting to ambush me, a lion in hiding

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are compared to filthy scum and refuse. This could mean: (1) God has caused the nations to think of his people as worthless. Alternate translation: “You have made the nations think of us as scum and garbage” or (2) God’s forcing his people to live among the nations is like throwing them away as garbage. Alternate translation: “You have thrown us away like filthy garbage among the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: You have made us like filthy scum and refuse among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people in Jerusalem are compared to ostriches because they are cruel to their children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of my people & like the ostriches in the desert

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their dry skin is compared to dry wood. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: it has become as dry as wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author compares the speed of their pursuers to the speed of eagles flying. Eagles fly very quickly to catch other animals. Alternate translation: “Those who were chasing us were faster than eagles” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Our pursuers were swifter than the eagles in the sky

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the peoples’ bodies being hot and feverish as if their skin was as hot as an oven. The people have fever because of their hunger. Alternate translation: “Our skin has become hot like an oven, and we have a very high fever because we are extremely hungry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Our skin has grown as hot as an oven because of the burning heat of hunger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people from various nations, not the entire population of those nations. Alternate translation: “people from the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to food in general. Alternate translation: “food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here all of the people of Jerusalem who were taken into captivity are represented by the “virgins” and the “vigorous men” who were taken. Alternate translation: “Many of my people, including my virgins and vigorous men, have gone into captivity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: My virgins and my vigorous men have gone into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the woman, representing Jerusalem, refers to her “heart” to emphasize her feelings. Alternate translation: “my heart is broken” or “I am extremely sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart is disturbed within me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “heart” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “I am faint” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart is faint

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the word **her** may refer either to the temple or to Jersualem. Possible translations are: (1) “the walls of the temple” or (2) “the walls of Jerusalem’s palaces.” The word “walls” is a synecdoche for the whole building, and the building is a synecdoche for all of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the walls of her palaces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word **heart** represents the whole person emphasizing one’s innermost being. Possible meanings of who cried out are: (1) the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “The people of Jerusalem shouted to the Lord from their innermost being” or (2) the walls are being personified. Alternate translation: “You walls, cry out to the Lord from your innermost being” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Their heart cried out to the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the women are represented by their “hands.” Because they were so hungry, women who had been compassionate in the past were no longer compassionate toward their children; instead they boiled them for food. Alternate translation: “Compassionate women” or “Women who had been compassionate in the past” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The hands of compassionate women

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “her foundations” represents the whole city, even the part of the city that would be ruined last. Alternate translation: “that burned down the city, even its foundations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: that consumed her foundations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the whole person and emphasizes their emotions. Alternate translation: “Our joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The joy of our heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “desperation” can be expressed as an adjective. Alternate translation: “when she was desperate” or “when she was distressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: in her desperation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “captivity” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “Her enemy captures her little children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Her little children go into captivity to her adversary

contextId.occurrenceNote: This word “destruction” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “because she was destroyed” or “while they destroyed her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: at her destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sorrow” can be expressed as a “sad.” Alternate translation: “see how extremely sad I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: see my sorrow

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “mourning” and “lamentation” can be expressed as verbs. Alternate translation: “He has caused more and more people within the daughter of Judah to mourn and lament” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: He has increased mourning and lamentation within the daughter of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “utterances” can be expressed with the verb “spoke.” Alternate translation: “they spoke things to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: for you they gave utterances

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **steadfast love**, you can express the same idea with the phrase “love faithfully.” Alternate translation: “Yahweh never stops loving his people faithfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: The steadfast love of Yahweh never ceases

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **compassions**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “care.” Alternate translation: “he never stops caring for those who suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: his compassions never end

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “panic,” “pitfall,” “ruin” and “destruction” can be expressed with verbs. Alternate translation: “we are panicking. We are trapped, and we are being ruined and destroyed” or “we are terrified and trapped. We are being completely destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: panic and pitfall have come upon us, ruin and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **scorn**, you can express the same idea with the verbs “taunt” or “mock.” It can be stated clearly that the plans were to harm him. Alternate translation: “You heard how they have taunted me … and all they plan to do to me” or “You have heard them mock me … and plan ways to harm me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You have heard their scorn & and all their plans regarding me

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **condemnation**, you can express the same idea with the verbs “condemn” or “curse.” Alternate translation: “Condemn them” or “Curse them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: May your condemnation be upon them

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **help**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “for people to help us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: for help

contextId.occurrenceNote: “your punishment will end.” The abstract noun punishment can be expressed with the verb “punish.” Alternate translation: “Yahweh will stop punishing you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: your punishment will come to an end

contextId.occurrenceNote: “forced to become a slave.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “but she is now a slave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: forced into slavery

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “has become an object of scorn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: has become scorned

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the sorrow that Yahweh is inflicting upon me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the sorrow that is being inflicted on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “caused the people in Zion to forget both solemn assembly and Sabbath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: caused both solemn assembly and Sabbath to be forgotten in Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Should our enemies slaughter priests and prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Should priest and prophet be slaughtered

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can stated in active form. Alternate translation: “because enemies have destroyed my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: because my people are destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those who grew up wearing scarlet clothing” or “those who wore scarlet clothing when they were growing up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Those who were brought up wearing scarlet clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “which” refers to Sodom. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “which God destroyed in a moment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: which was overthrown in a moment

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one wrung their hands for her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: no hands were wrung for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one can recognize them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they are not recognized

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of things being turned over to others can be expressed with an active form. Since it is also understood in the second part of the sentence, those words can be repeated there. Alternate translation: “You have turned our inheritance over to strangers; you have turned our houses over to strangers” or “You have allowed strangers to take possession of our inheritance; you have allowed foreigners to take possession of our houses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Our inheritance has been turned over to strangers; our houses to foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “our enemies sell us our own wood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: we must pay silver to get our own wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Our enemies have raped the women … and the virgins” or “Our enemies have violated the women … and the virgins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Women are raped & and virgins

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they have shown no honor to the elders” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: no honor is shown to the elders

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “They force young men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Young men are forced

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase with the quote following it gives us more information about the king. The quote shows what the people had hoped the king would do for them before he was trapped. It can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “even though we had said about him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: of whom it was said

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh being very angry as if his anger cannot be measured. This is an exaggeration. Alternate translation: “are extremely angry with us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: are angry with us beyond measure

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases refer to people. These two opposites are used to refer to all ages of people. Alternate translation: “Both young people and old people” or “People of all ages” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Both the young and the old

Singular Pronouns that refer to Groups
